loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fish vending business in the Philippines. She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

She is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy more fish to sell to her customers. NWTF is re-listing Feliciana's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell at her food stall.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
This is Corazon. She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to buy more stocks of mineral water needed in her mineral water distribution business. Her earnings were a big help for her family's personal, household and business expenditures.

Corazon is requesting another 10,000 PHP loan to buy additional stocks of mineral water for her business. The more mineral water she displays at her store, the better, as more stock will result in better profit. Corazon's business profits will definitely help sustain her daily needs and she looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. In the future, Corazon dreams that her business will continue to grow and she hopes that her children will have a better life. She meets up weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy mineral water to distribute for her business

loans.name: Irma

texts.es: Irma, de 55 años de edad , está casada con Manuel quien es empleado y tiene 2 hijos con quienes vive en su casa propia.El negocio que tiene Irma es la venta de comidas durante los fines de semana por está razón ha acondicionado un pequeño espacio en la vereda de su casa y ahí ofrece a la venta platillos regionales como juanes, pollos fritos, asados y otros, atiende siempre de manera amable y cordial a su distinguida clientela. Su actividad empieza levantándose muy temprano para realizar las compras de sus ingredientes para la preparación de los platillos que ofrecerá durante el día. Ya  lleva más de 16  años en éste negocio y cuenta con el apoyo de su hija y de su nuera  para atender al público. Le gusta su negocio pues le ha traído muchas satisfacciones personales y económicas, asegura que es una actividad que no requiere de mucho esfuerzo físico más de lo debido y eso le permite seguir adelante, desea que su trabajo permanezca estable para que continúe trabajando.Este es el préstamo número 05 con Kiva, está muy agradecida por la oportunidad crediticia que le brindan y por el respaldo financiero que necesita para seguir adelante. Con el monto solicitado de 2000 nuevos soles comprará víveres e ingredientes tales como arroz, plátanos, harina, huevos,entre otros, para la preparación de una mayor variedad de platillos, también comprará gaseosas.
texts.en: Irma is 55 years old.  She is married to Manuel, who has a job, and they have two children.  They live together in their own house.  Irma has a business selling meals at the weekend.  She has a small space on the pavement outside her home for her business and it is there that she sells typical, regional dishes such as "juanes" (a rice and meat dish), fried chicken and roast meats.  Irma always offers friendly and polite service to her customers.  She starts very early when she goes out to buy her ingredients for the dishes she will be selling each day.  She has had the business for 16 years and receives support from her daughter and daughter-in-law to attend to customers.  Irma likes her business as it has brought her a lot of financial and personal satisfaction.  She says that the work does not require much physical effort and so she is able to move forward in life.  Irma would like her work to remain stable so that she may continue to work.  This is her fifth loan with Kiva and she is very grateful for the loan opportunity she is being given and for the financial support that she needs to continue.  With the loan of 2000 Nuevo Soles, she will buy supplies and ingredients such as rice, plantains, flour and eggs to prepare a greater variety of dishes.  She will also buy fizzy drinks.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as rice, plantains, flour and more.

loans.name: Kucup Mekar Group

texts.en:
Kucup Mekar group got a loan for the seventh time. There are 17 members and the total loan is 22.1M IDR. One member is not present in the photo  because of sickness. 

Having been successful with maintaining and fattening pigs, Ni Ketut will use this loan to purchase four types of local pigs for pork roll and maintain them for two months and then sell them. She will use the remainder of the loan to fix the cage to prepare for a new litter from a sow that she already owns. 

The price of pig feed is currently very expensive, but she remains optimistic about this business going forward. With all the benefits she gets, she plans to repair her home and also save for capital for the business.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and feed, and prepare for a litter of piglets.

loans.name: Bat-Orgil

texts.en:
Mr. Bat-Orgil, 35 years old, lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. The family resides in their own house on a plot of land. He has the position of petroleum supply operator at a petroleum importing company. He works for twenty-four hours and then takes the next two days off. During his days off, he renders taxi service to local people using his own automobile. 

He is requesting a loan of 2,500,000 MNT to purchase some building materials, such as planks, bricks and steel. Using those materials, he will make an extension to his house, and it will certainly improve his family's living situation by providing more space and resulting in reduced heat loss through the walls. Bat-Orgil is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to make an extension to his house in order to reduce heat loss.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
This is Mary Jane, 22, resident of Payatas, Philippines. She is married to Juan Miguel, a worker, and they have children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Mary Jane operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php500 in sales every day.

She is requesting a Php10,000 loan to help her continue in the operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Mary Jane hopes that her business will grow and dreams to have more business.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en: Marivic, 38 years old, is married and lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur, with three children. She is earning money from her transportation service business. It has been going for almost three years now, and she earns about PHP 15,000 a month. To improve business, she is borrowing the amount of PHP 35,000 from GDMPC microcredit, which she joined recently to obtain accessories and tires. She’s hopeful of the possibility of expanding her business before long.

loans.use: to obtain accessories and tires.

loans.name: Lezel

texts.en:
Lezel is 34 years old, married with four children, and two of her children are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. She has a shell-crafting business in the Philippines. Lezel has been in this business for six years.

She requested a PHP 10,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy materials needed for her shell-crafting business. In the future, Lezel would like to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy materials needed for her shell-crafting business.

loans.name: Biasha

texts.en:
Biasha is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. For the past three years, she has sold firewood from her home, selling to local neighbors. Biasha owns a house without electricity or running water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and water and her major business challenge is seasonality. Biasha decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

Biasha is requesting a 10,000 KES loan to purchase firewood to sell. In the future, she dreams of establishing a poultry business.

loans.use: to purchase firewood to sell

loans.name: Oyunbileg

texts.en:
Oyunbileg, 38 years old, lives with her family in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family resides in their own house on a plot of land. Her younger sister has a position of designer at a private business entity. She herself has been working as a laboratory technician at a center of disability research. 

The house they live in has been deteriorating over the years and needs some serious repair. So she is requesting a loan of 4,000,000 MNT to cover the costs of purchasing building and insulation materials such as planks, gypsum, fiber glass, foams and metals and installing a sanitation system into the house. This will increase energy efficiency. Because the family previously used coal to warm water and heat the house, the renovated house will enable the family to burn less coal, emit less smoke and contribute to the efforts against air pollution. 

The borrower is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase building and insulation materials.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort runs a grocery store and sells provisions in Hotopo, near Takoradi. She is married with four children and has been educated through the end of middle school. Comfort's husband is currently unemployed.  She is the sole provider for her family and has been running her store for four years now. Comfort is responsible for paying the family's utility bills and her children's school fees. 

Comfort is requesting a loan to increase her stock of merchandise. She hopes to use the profits from her loan to expand her business and increase her capital base. In the long run, Comfort wants to expand her business into neighboring villages.

loans.use: to purchase provisions and increase her stock levels

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel highly appreciates Kiva's $50 loan support. He has been able to increase his customer base and is now making more money from recharging the LED lights. 

He is seeking a top up loan of $50 to purchase 10 more rechargeable LED lights, which he will resell to people without electricity in his village. Every week or so, these customers will return to him to have their lights recharged for just $0.20. 

He started selling lights in June, 2012 and he has sold 40 lights (10 with the support of Kiva) to date, providing clean energy to 200 people. He plans to reinvest the money he makes into expanding his other business to earn more money for himself and his wife.

loans.use: To pay for 10 low-cost LED lights to resell to rural households without electricity.

loans.name: Bebelyn

texts.en:
This is Bebelyn. She previously accessed an 8,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children's education, as well as in the family's personal, household and business expenditures. She makes door mats, pot holders and rugs.

She would like to apply for another 8,000 PHP loan for her to buy additional supplies of raw materials needed in her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her family’s daily needs and her children's education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Bebelyn hopes for a continuous growth in her business and dreams that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials like fabric, thread, needles and other materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en: Aurelia is 50 years old and married with 3 children. She lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She owns and operates a general store to earn a living. She has been in her business for over 8 years and earns about 1, every month. She joined GDMPC in 2010, and now she has requested a loan of 4,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods, shampoo and soap. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods, shampoo and soap.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is married and she works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell.

She has been in this business for five years and has previously received funds through Kiva. She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further improve her business. Lydia aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en: This time, for her 10th loan cycle, Leticia is borrowing 17,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to fund her fish pond business. Her fishing business that she previously funded through Kiva partner NWTF continues to provide her and her family with income that is improving their quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of feeds for her fish pond.

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en:
Maxima is a 58-year-old married woman and a mother of adult children. She is from Bohol, Philippines. For more than 12 years, Maxima has been a vegetable farmer together with her husband.

Maxima is requesting a loan to buy seedlings, fertilizer, and pesticide for her farm. She will use her loan to grow and harvest good quality vegetables to increase her yield and profit.

loans.use: to buy seedlings, fertilizer, and pesticide for her farm

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth is 32 years old and married with one child. She lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. For the past five years, Janeth has been a farmer who plants and harvests rice on her land to earn a living. She earns 10,000 PHP each month and joined GDMPC in 2011.

Janeth is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan to purchase fertilizer such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated with her loan to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe    BENKADI   est constitué de 6 femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et 6 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs maris, coépouses, frères et fils dans le village de Sido. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur troisième  prêt. Les 2 précédents prêts ont été correctement remboursés. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de boissons à l’image de DJOBA, qui  a une douzaine de boissons sur son pied. Elle fait l’achat vente de  boissons et compte acheter avec son  prêt 20 casiers de boissons avec les grossistes de Bamako. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle mixte. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The BENKADI group consists of 6 married women who average 34 years of age and six children. They live in extended traditional families with their husbands, other wives, brothers and sons in the village of Sido.

They know one another as neighbors and friends, and through their commercial activities. To strengthen their working capital and improve their activities, they joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they have reached their third loan cycle. Both past loans were repaid correctly. 

These women sell soft drinks. DJOBA, for instance, is shown in the photo with a case of a dozen soft drinks on her lap. She plans to use her loan to buy 20 cases of soft drinks from wholesalers in Bamako. She sells at retail to a mixed clientele, from her home and at the market, accepting cash and credit.

She expects to earn an average monthly profit of 30,000FCFA, which she will use to repay the loan and reinvest in her activity.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks for resale.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en: Luzviminda is 37 years old and married to a tricycle driver. Her husband is patiently operating their own tricycle, while she manages a piggery business. They work hard to promote their living. In helping her husband, she is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) to buy new tires and paint and pay for maintenance for their tricycle. Luzviminda hopes to improve her business in the future and to develop her piggery business more.

loans.use: to buy new tires and paint and pay for maintenance.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en:
Estrella is 36 years old, married and has eight children.

Estrella is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. Estrella requested a 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Estrella has been raising pigs for two years now, and has borrowed three times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Estrella would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana is 25 years of age and married.  She manages her time wisely on both her farming and her studies.

Diana operates a rice field and her retail store. She has been engaged in her rice farming business for more than three years. Diana wants to maintain her rice field as productive and profitable, so she is asking for a loan of PHP 50,000 to buy necessary farm inputs for her rice field.

She hopes and prays that lenders will grant her the requested loan amount to provide her rice field with the proper care and nutrition. In this way, she could earn better income, which will be used to cover all their household expenses and fully pay her tuition fee.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs for her rice farming business.

loans.name: Shakir

texts.en:
Shakir is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) from Fuzuli. He lives in the Absheron region with his family. He is 52 years old, married, and has two children - a 20-year-old daughter and an 18-year-old  son. His daughter is married and has a child. Shakir's son wants to become a firefighter. His wife stays at home, so he is the only one making an income. 

This is Shakir's third loan from Kiva. He started his business 2 years ago, selling fruits and vegetables. Now he needs a 2,000 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat) loan to repair his shop and to make shelves inside the store for displaying the goods. Shakhir is thankful to Komak and Kiva for supporting him again.

loans.use: to repair his shop.

loans.name: Elvar

texts.en:
Elvar is 29 years old. He lives in Marneuli District with his 23-year-old wife and parents. Elvar requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

Elvar and his father are artisans. They work on house renovations on private orders and get small monthly salaries, which are rarely enough to cover the family's monthly expenses.

Elvar requested a loan from Credo to start up a family business. Elvar has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit, Elvar will purchase a mini-bus. He will start trading with fruits and vegetables. Elvar will buy products from the big market, transport them to the local markets and sell them to the resellers and among the villagers with the price markup. This business will bring a good profit to Elvar. He will use part of the profit for reinvesting in the same field to purchase more products and to be able to offer better choice to the clients. Another part, Elvar will use for the family's well-being. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: To buy a mini-bus to transport fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Jacintar

texts.en:
Jacintar is 51 years old and married to Julius, who is a teacher and contributes to the family income. Jacintar has been running her posho mill business for a period of about 10 years with an income of approximately KES 11,050 a month. (A posho mill grinds maize.)

This is her first loan from KADET LTD and wants to use the loan to buy cereals such as maize, and also beans to sell. She hopes to open another posho mill and expand the business.

loans.use: to buy cereals such as maize, and also beans to sell.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
After graduating from Junior high school, Esther decided to set up her own dressmaking  business in Hotopo (near Cape Coast). With over 3 years' experience, she is currently looking to expand her enterprise further. Unfortunately, she is limited due to a lack of funding. 

As a result, this loan will be used to help her to purchase an additional sewing machine to make her work easier. She aims at using the profits from her business to help support her husband (who is a driver) with the upkeep of their house, while ensuring that their one child is able to experience a better life.

loans.use: to purchase an additional sewing machine to make her work easier.

loans.name: Maritta

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Maritta works hard to support her family. She has a food production business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store.  

Maritta is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients and utensils for her food production business. She has been sustaining her business activities through her past 8 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients and utensils for her food production business.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer is 42 years old and married with 5 children. She lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She owns and operates a retail business to earn a living. She has been in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000PHP every month. 

She joined GDMPC in 2010, and now she has requested a loan of 10,000PHP to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods, shampoo, soap, sugar and coffee. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods, shampoo, soap, sugar and coffee.

loans.name: Bonny Claribel

texts.es:
Bonny tiene 28 años de edad, esta acompañada y tiene dos hijos de 5 años de edad y otro de dos meses. Desde hace cinco años administra su propia tienda y un molino de nixtamal. Antes vendía frutas y verduras de manera ambulante; pero cuando se acompaño se cambio de domicilio y poco a poco fue instalando su tienda, pero debido a los gastos del nacimiento de su segundo hijo, la tienda decreció, por falta de dinero para invertir.  Se levanta a las 5:00 a.m. a abrir la tienda y atender a sus clientes. Los productos para su tienda, los adquiere en la ciudad; para llegar ahí debe caminar a pie hasta llegar  a la carretera en donde aborda un pick up que tarda cuarenta y cinco minutos hasta llegar a su destino. 

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar un quintal de azúcar, un quintal de arroz, un quintal de sal, cuatro cajas de jabón, cinco galones de aceite, 25 docenas de lejía, cinco fardos de detergente, papel higiénico, etc y la otra parte pagara algunos gastos que le quedaron pendiente del parto. Será de mucha utilidad el préstamo, ya que podrá surtir su tienda de una variedad de productos y quedara solvente con los gastos del parto. Sus grandes son el que su tienda sea más grande y con muchos clientes y que sus hijos estudien en la universidad, debido a que ella no tuvo esa oportunidad.
texts.en:
Bonny, age 28, is in a relationship, and she has two children.  One is five years old, and the other is two months.  She has been running her own store and a corn flour mill for five years.  Before that she sold fruit and vegetables in an itinerant manner.  However, when she entered into a relationship she changed houses.  Little by little, she was setting up her store.  However, due the expenses of the birth of her second child, the store declined because of the lack of money to invest.

She gets up a 5:00 a.m. to open the store and tend to her customers.  She gets the products for her store in the city.  In order to do so, she has to walk on foot until she gets to the road where she boards a pickup.  It takes 45 minutes to get to her destination.

The loan that she is requesting from the Fundación Campo is to buy a ‘quintal’ [1 quintal = 100 kg] of sugar, a quintal of rice, a quintal of salt, four cases of soap, five gallons of cooking oil, 25 dozen packets of bleach, five cases of detergent, and toilet paper, etc.  With the other part of the loan she will pay some expenses she still has from the birth.

The loan will be very useful because she will be able to stock her store with a variety of products and she will become solvent with the birth expenses.  

Her biggest wishes are for her store to get bigger with lots of customers and for her children to attend the university because she did not have this opportunity.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a small-scale food vendor in Hotopo (near Takoradi). She has had some form of formal education as she is a middle school level graduate. She is married and has one child. Her husband is a driver.  

Grace has been working as a food vendor for close to six years. As a provider in the family, the proceeds from her business normally go toward covering the entire family’s general expenses. She plans on using her loan to purchase an increased quantity of foodstuffs and other ingredients, thus allowing her to meet rising customer demand. She hopes to use the profits from her enterprise to fulfill her dream of mounting a food stand, hence helping her sell from a fixed location in the future.

loans.use: to purchase an increased quantity of foodstuffs and other ingredients.

loans.name: Dusan

texts.en:
Dusan, 51, is a married male who lives in a minority community with his wife and his son, who is 19 years old. For more than 20 years, he has run his own business as a hairdresser in his area. He is very professional in his work, which allows him to have lot of clients and generate more income than others. 

To generate more income, Dusan also is employed as a teacher in a high school, and his wife works in a municipality.

Dusan now requests a loan to buy equipment for opening a new hairdressing salon in his area. This loan will help him to allow and develop his business and increase the number of clients. He will use the income generated from the business to support his family and to save for his future. In the future, he plans to develop his business more and to expand by opening more hairdressing salons. He is very happy for this opportunity and thanks all Kiva lenders!

loans.use: To buy equipment for opening a hairdressing salon.

loans.name: Analou

texts.en:
Analou is 29 years old and married with 3 children.  With two children in school, Analou works very hard to provide for them. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell.

She has been in this business for five years and sells a variety of items, such as shampoo, sardines, noodles and other groceries. In the future, Analou would like to save enough to build a house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Although she has received no prior formal education, Agnes is an entrepreneur. She specializes in the selling of provisions in Hotopo (near Takoradi). She has been involved in this enterprise for 3 years.  She is married and has 6 children. Her husband works as a farmer. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and to pay their children’s school fees. 

Agnes wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, allowing her to sell greater quantities of provisions. In the long term, Agnes plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her to expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to buy greater quantities of provisions.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is 47 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She owns and operates a retail business to earn a living. She has been in her business for over 6 years and earns about 2,000 PHP every month. 

She joined GDMPC in 2010, and now she has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, like shampoo, soap, sugar and coffee. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell, like shampoo, soap, sugar and coffee.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Although she has received no prior formal education, Linda is an entrepreneur. She specializes in preparing and selling ‘Banku’ (a traditional Ghanaian dish made using fermented corn/cassava dough that is mixed proportionally and cooked in hot water into a smooth whitish consistent paste). She usually sells her ‘Banku’ in Hotopo (near Takoradi). She has been involved in preparing and selling ‘Banku’ for 3 years. 

Linda is married and has 3 children. Her husband works as a driver. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and to pay their children’s school fees. Linda wants to use her loan to purchase a greater quantity of cassava and maize, thus increasing her current inventory levels. As a result, this will allow her to sell greater quantities of her tasty ‘Banku’. In the long term, Linda plans to reinvest the future profits back into her business, thus helping her to expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to purchase a greater quantity of cassava and maize.

loans.name: Peris

texts.en: Peris is a resident of Kisii. She is married and has four children. She has been farming for ten years, producing bananas, maize and milk. She has applied for a loan of KES 41,600 to buy and insure a dairy cow. This will increase her milk production and hence increase her level of income. She expects to achieve a high yield in her production in the next five years. She says that lack of markets is her major challenge.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow for her farm.

loans.name: Divinagracia

texts.en: Farming has been the business of Divina Gracia for more than 14 years. She owns 1.3 hectares of rice fields. Divina Gracia is 35 years old, married, and has two children. Her older child goes to school, and her younger child is still an infant. Divina Gracia would like to borrow PHP 40,000. She will use this loan to buy farm supplies that are needed to make her rice farm productive and profitable. In this way, she can earn a better income, which will serve to sustain her family’s daily needs and educate her two children. She hopes and prays that her loan will be granted.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, two sacks of seedlings and insecticides for her farming business.

loans.name: Indelicia

texts.en: Indelicia is married, and she works hard to support her family. She has a business selling ice cream in the Philippines, and she earns additional income from fishing. Indelicia is borrowing PHP 14,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for making ice cream. Indelicia has been sustaining her business activities with her past six loans from NWTF and, more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of repairing and renovating her family home.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to make ice cream to sell.

loans.name: Brian

texts.en:
Brian is a Business Management Student of the Maharishi Institute. Brian is 20 years old and was asked the following questions by a staff member of the Institute:


What do you study at the Maharishi Institute and what classes do you enjoy most?
“I am studying Bachelor of Business Administration and the classes I enjoy the most are English, Leadership and Principles of Business Success.”

What are your goals after graduation?
“I would like to be employed in a very successful company and be placed in the HR department. I also would like to start my own business. I would like to work in Johannesburg City (South Africa, Gauteng).”


Tell us about your background?
“I was born in Limpopo (SA), I am the firstborn in the family with only one younger sister. My mother is a domestic worker and she is the one who puts the food on the table. She divorced my father when I was still young. I am not married and I don’t have any children.”

What do you do in your spare time?
“What I like doing in my spare time is producing music and I also hang out with friends.”

How will the Kiva Loan change your life?
“My life will be more successful, I won’t have to worry about being expelled from school because I would be owing. My lifestyle will change because I will now be able to cover all my expenses with the extra money I get from Kiva and it's all a good thing for my studies because I will be able to buy some things I need.”

loans.use: to pay for one year of tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
This is Carmelita. She previously accessed an 11,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan that she used to buy spare parts and accessories and pay for the maintenance of the jeepney unit. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in her personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for a new 15,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and pay for the maintenance of the jeepney unit. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and her children's education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Carmelita dreams to have more. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.


Curiously, jeepneys have purely American origins. They were first used by American soldiers helping the Philippines throw off the invading Japanese. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater jeepney, open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for everyday travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. Now, the jeepneys are one of the things that makes the Philippines truly Philippines.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for spare parts and maintenance of the jeepney unit.

loans.name: Mercidita

texts.en:
Mercidita is 39 years old, is married and has six dependents. She lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. Mercidita has run a sari-sari (variety) store for two years, earning a monthly income of 15,000 PHP (Philippines pesos). 

In 2010, Mercidita became a member of GDMPC. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 PHP to buy items such as milk, diapers, food products, etc. With the loan, Mercidita hopes to boost her income and improve her family’s general living conditions.

loans.use: to buy items such as milk, diapers, food products, etc.

loans.name: Parviz

texts.en:
Parviz is 38 years old, married, and has three children, 7-year-old and 11-year-old daughters and a 4-year-old son. His daughters go to school and his son goes to preschool. His wife stays at home, so he is the only one making an income. 

Parviz has been an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) from Agdam. Now he lives in the Absheron region . This is Parviz's third loan from Kiva. He started his business  14 years ago. Now he needs a 1,500 AZN (Azerbaijan New Manat) loan to repair his car. He wants to use the money from his new and increased income to help his family. He changed his car after the second loan from Kiva. This will be more profitable for his business.

 Parviz is thankful to Komak and Kiva for supporting him again.

loans.use: to repair his car, used as a taxi

loans.name: 04-07-12-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Ms. Thu operates a food stall/restaurant, selling noodles. She is requesting a loan to purchase pork to make processed food to resell.

Thu is 26 years old, and she is single with no children. Thu lives with no dependents in Thanh Hoa city, an urban town in Thanh Hoa province.

Thu is the group leader of the 04-07-12-Nam Ngạn solidarity group, which consists of eight members. This is Thu's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund of Poor Women.

Thu has been involved in this business for five years. The main hardship that Thu faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Thu hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, to build a new house, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase pork to make processed food to resell.

loans.name: Ma. Cheryl

texts.en:
Ma. Cheryl is 42 years old and married with two children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Ma. Cheryl has a fishing business in the Philippines. Ma. Cheryl requested a 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan amount through NWTF to buy fishing net and other equipment.

Ma. Cheryl has been in this business for 17 years. In the future, Ma. Cheryl would like to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to buy fishing net and other equipment.

loans.name: Cindy Elizabeth

texts.es:
Cindy es una mujer de 22 años, vive en la ciudad de Cañete, en el distrito de Imperial con sus padres y hermanos, ella es una persona muy amable, trabajadora y entusiasta, que tiene un gran deseo de superación; lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos y por la necesidad que tuvo de trabajar desde muy joven para ayudar a sus padres, Cindy no ha podido estudiar la carrera profesional de Computación e Informática, pero le gustaría poder hacerlo, en sus ratos libres le gusta hacer deporte y en algunas ocasiones cocina un riquísimo Ají de Gallina para compartir con su familia.
Por iniciativa propia, con mucho empeño y dedicación, Cindy trabaja como auxiliar en un centro educativo inicial de su ciudad, adicionalmente los fines de semana trabaja en su hogar vendiendo frutas, ella trabaja todos los días por un aproximado de 10 horas y cree que le va bien por su buen desempeño y por el trato amable que brinda a los demás.
Cindy se encuentra muy agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada podrá realizar la compra de una vitrina, la cual le servirá de mucho para poder exhibir algunas frutas que vende, así pues Cindy seguirá trabajando y esforzándose para lograr su gran sueño de poder convertirse en una buena profesional y poco a poco al lado de su familia desea salir adelante.
texts.en:
Cindy is 22 years old and lives in the city of Cañete, in the Imperial district, with her parents and brothers.  She is friendly, hard-working and enthusiastic, with a strong desire to get ahead in life.  Unfortunately, due to a lack of financial resources and because she had to work from a young age to help her parents, Cindy was not able to study computing and information technology as she would have liked.  In her spare time she enjoys playing sports and she sometime cooks a delicious "aji de gallina" (a typical, chicken-based Peruvian dish) to share with her family.

Under her own initiative, and with a lot of determination and dedication, Cindy works as an assistant in a nursery school in her city.  In addition, on weekends, she works at home, selling fruits.  Cindy works every day for around ten hours and she believes her work is going well because of her determination and because of the friendly service she gives to customers.

Cindy is very grateful to Kiva lenders as, thanks to the help provided, she will be able to purchase a display case, that will help her to put the fruits she is selling on display.  Cindy will continue working and putting in the effort so that she can achieve her big dream of becoming a professional. Little by little, and alongside her family, she wants to prosper in life.

loans.use: to buy a display cabinet.

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is married and has two children. They reside in Kitale. She has been a farmer for the past five years, producing and selling poultry products, horticulture and milk in the local market. Besides farming, she also has a retail business.

She has requested a loan of KES 30,000 to fund her poultry project. This will boost her income and improve their standard of living. In the future, Justine wants to acquire land for more production. The challenges she faces in this business are inadequate capital, diseases and the high cost of production.

loans.use: To purchase poultry.

loans.name: Cresencia

texts.en:
Cresencia works hard to support her family. She is married and has a general store business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for 15 years.

She requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more grocery items, such as sardines, soap, seasonings and other miscellaneous items. In the future, Cresencia would like to save enough to support the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery items, such as sardines, soap, seasonings and other miscellaneous items.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
As a married mother of two children, Eva works hard to support her family.

Eva has a computer rental business in the Philippines. She also earns additional income from a general store. Eva is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy computer supplies for her computer rental business.

Eva has been sustaining her business activities through her past 19 loans from NWTF and, more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy computer supplies for her computer rental business.

loans.name: Mamuka

texts.en:
Mamuka is 47 years old. He lives in a small village of Mtskheta District with his father and son. His father is provided with a retirement pension. Mamuka requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of the income for the family is the monthly income of Mamuka, working as an artisan locally. It is hardly enough for food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Mamuka requested loan from Credo to start up a family business. Mamuka has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit Mamuka will build a greenhouse.  He plans to purchase all the needed raw materials and build himself a greenhouse where he will sow cucumbers and tomatoes. Mamuka will sell the harvested products at local markets and increase the income of the family. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to build a greenhouse

loans.name: Nina

texts.en: Nina is 48 years old. She lives in a small village in Kareli District. Nina applied for loans from local financial institutions several times, for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected every time because of her low income and her family’s poor living conditions. Nina is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, she has 1.25 hectares of agricultural land, where different kinds of vegetables are grown seasonally. It provides barely enough food for the family. According to Credo's assessment, the family belongs in the "subsistence poor" category. Nina has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits on soft conditions to rural poor people who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. The client received the first part (tranche) of the start-up loan, which will be used to buy green bean, tomato and cabbage seeds. Within 30 days after loan disbursement, Credo will monitor the client and, if the loan purpose has been met, will disburse the second tranche, which will be used to hire agricultural workers to help Nina in developing her farming business. After buying the seeds, she will be able to sow them and have a harvest in a few months. The products she harvests will be sold at local markets, and Nina will increase her income. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy green bean, tomato and cabbage seeds to improve her farming activities.

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina is 40 years old, married, and has one child. She lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She owns and operates a general store in her community to earn a living. She has been in her business for over three years and earns 10,000 PHP every month. She joined GDMPC in the year 2011, and now she has applied for a loan of 15,000 PHP to buy additional products to sell, such as vegetables, coffee and sugar. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell, such as vegetables, coffee and sugar.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for one year of tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn is 38 years old, married, and has five children who are all in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Jovelyn has a fishing business in the Philippines. Jovelyn requested a PHP 13,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

Jovelyn has been in this business for 13 years. In the future, Jovelyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 24-year-old single man who has been working in the construction business for eight years. He is specialized in external rock work. Ali is talented in his business and well known in the region, with his hard work to prove himself among competitors. He is energetic and  skilled in what he does.

Ali is applying for a YOUTH loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua, in order to buy new updated tools and machines that will make his work easier (special rock-cutting machine).

He is looking forward to expanding his working zone to increase his customers and develop his business.

loans.use: to buy new updated tools

loans.name: Emie

texts.en: Emie is 35 years old, married with three children. She lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She owns and operates a dried fish vending business to earn a living. She has been in her business for over five years and earns 15,000 PHP every month. She joined GDMPC in the year 2010, and now she has requested a loan of 25,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell like dried fish.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like dried fish

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio is 53 years old and married with three children. He lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. He owns and operates a business planting and harvesting squash, which he sells in the local community to earn a living. He has been in this business for more than eight years and earns 8,000 PHP every month. He joined GDMPC in 2010.

Rogelio is now requesting a loan of 11,000 PHP to purchase additional seedlings and fertilizers. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase additional seedlings and fertilizers.

loans.name: Thokozani

texts.en:
Thokozani is a Business Management Student of the Maharishi Institute. Thokozani is 21 years old and was asked the following questions by a staff member of the Institute:

What do you study at the Maharishi Institute and what classes do you enjoy most?
“Bachelor of Business Administration. I enjoy Principles of Business Success, Principles of Economics and Business Fundamentals.”

What are your goals after graduation?
“I plan to get a job as a manager, work for approximately three years and save up enough money for me to start my own business, and also continue studying via correspondence.”


Tell us about your background?
“I am the last born in a family of six. I have three brothers and two sisters. My mother is unemployed and my father works at an engineering firm. I am not married and don’t have any children.”


What do you do in your spare time?
“I like writing and reading, listening to music and watching inspirational documentaries.”


How will the Kiva Loan change your life?
“Firstly the loan will help me pay off my first year tuition, secondly the loan will help me with transport fare which is a major problem for me.”

loans.use: to pay for one year of tuition fees and living expenses at the Maharishi Institute.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
This is Lolita. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more garden inputs and she was able to sell more. This has been her business for ten years now. She and her husband are working hard to provide income to their family and to give their children a good future.

She would now like to apply for a 19,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy gardening materials like wire and baskets and supplies such as seed and fertilizer needed in her business. Her profits from her business will definitely help her cover their daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Lolita dreams of a continuous growth in her business. As a CCT community partner, she attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she also draws strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for gardening materials like wire and baskets and supplies such as seed and fertilizer needed in her business.

loans.name: Ma. Ketielyn

texts.en:
Ma. Ketielyn works hard to support her family. She is single and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Ma. Ketielyn requested a 13,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy a new engine for her fishing boat.

She has been in this business for four years.

In the future, Ma. Ketielyn would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy a new engine for her fishing boat.

loans.name: Gibran

texts.en:
Gibran is 35 years old and is a second-hand clothes dealer in Voi, Kenya. He is a married man who supports three children. He has been in this business for the last seven years and has done well.

This marks his seventh borrowing from KADET, to purchase bales of second-hand clothes for his kiosk. He will use the anticipated profit to expand his business as well as service his loan. He hopes to be an international second-hand clothes dealer in future.

loans.use: to purchase bales of second-hand clothes for his kiosk

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia is a 53-year-old married woman and the mother of 10 children. She is from Garcia-Hernandez, Bohol. Sofia has been engaged in a vegetable-farming business with her husband for more than 10 years now.

Sofia is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers and seedlings. With this loan, she will be able to improve her farm and grow good-quality vegetables. Sofia hopes to expand her farm and make it a success so that it will generate more revenue for her family's needs and expenses.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seedlings.

loans.name: 04-08-02-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hồng has a retail business selling coal. She is requesting a loan to purchase charcoal for resale and purchase pigs to raise.

Hồng is 29 years old and she is married with one child. Hồng is the group leader of the 04-08-02-Nam Ngạn solidarity group, which consists of four members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with no dependents; her child is grown up.

In 2009, Hồng joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Hồng has successfully repaid four loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Hồng has been involved in this business for 5 years. The main hardship that Hồng faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Hồng hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, to build a new house, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale and purchase pigs to raise.

loans.name: Alaa

texts.en:
Alaa is an 18-year-old single man who has been working raising sheep since three years ago. Alaa was only 15 years old when he started working raising sheep to help his parents in making their living and covering his expenses. He is applying for a youth loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua, in order to increase the number of sheep he is raising.

Alaa is working hard to improve his business and living to make sure that if he is going to have his own family in the future, not to let them face what he faced. He wants to make sure that they will have the best education ever.

loans.use: To increase his sheep.

loans.name: Siguikadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe   SIGUIKADI  est constitué de 5 femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur deuxième prêt. Le précédent prêt à été correctement remboursé. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de  céréales à l’image de SETOU ,qui est la seule femme assise dans la photo. Elle fait l’achat vente de céréales et compte acheter avec son  prêt, 800Kgde maïs avec les  paysans producteurs. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The group SIGUIKADI comprises five women, all married and averaging 30 years of age and four children each. The women live in traditional extended families in the Hérémakono Nord district of Bougouni City. They know one another through ties of community, friendship, and commerce. To bolster their financial capacity, so as to operate their businesses better, they joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second loan. The previous loan was indeed paid back. 

This group of women does commerce in grains, as does SETOU, who is the only women sitting in the photo. She buys and sells grains and intends to use her loan to purchase 800 kg of corn from peasant producers. Accepting cash or credit, she makes her sales at the market and at home to a customer base composed essentially of women. She envisions making an average monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that will be reinvested in her work and used to repay the loan.

loans.use: to purchase grains

loans.name: Akosua

texts.en: After graduating from primary school, Akosua decided to set up her own general store in Hotopo (near Takoradi). With more than 10 years of experience, she is currently looking to expand her enterprise further. Unfortunately, she is limited due to a lack of funds. As a result, this loan will be used to help her to purchase more provisions for resale. She plans to use the profits from her business to help support her husband (who is a farmer) with the upkeep of their house while ensuring that their three children are able to experience a better life.

loans.use: to purchase more provisions for resale.

loans.name: Nanette

texts.en: Nanette is 36 years old and married with four children. She lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She owns and operates a food stall where she sells snacks in the local community to earn a living. She has been in her business for more than six years and earns 15,000 PHP every month. She joined  GDMPC in 2010, and now she has requested a loan of 30,000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell such as bananas, bread and juice. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell such as bananas, bread and juice.

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  SABALI  est constitué de 5 femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs maris, coépouses, frères et fils dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur deuxième prêt. Le précédent prêt à été correctement remboursé. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de  céréales à l’image de SITAN ,qui est la première femme de la droite vers la gauche.  Elle fait l’achat vente de  céréales et compte acheter avec son  prêt,  800 Kg de maïs avec les villageois. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The group SABALI comprises five women, all married and averaging 32 years of age and four children each. The women live in traditional extended families with their husbands, co-wives, brothers, and sons in the Hérémakono Nord district of Bougouni City. They know one another through ties of community, friendship, and commerce. To bolster their financial capacity, so as to operate their businesses better, they joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second loan. The previous loan was indeed paid back. 

This group of women does commerce in grains, as does SITAN, who is the first women on the right in the photo. She buys and sells grains and intends to use her loan to purchase 800 kg of corn from villagers. Accepting cash or credit, she makes her sales retail at the market and at home to a customer base composed essentially of women. She envisions making an average monthly profit of 25,000 francs CFA that will be reinvested in her work and used to repay the loan.

loans.use: to purchase grains

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  SABALI  est constitué de 6 femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs maris, coépouses, frères et fils dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur deuxième prêt. Le précédent prêt à été correctement remboursé. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de  céréales à l’image de AWA,qui est la .première femme de gauche vers la droite dans la photo. Elle fait l’achat vente de  céréales et compte acheter avec son  prêt, 2 tonnes de maïs avec les paysans producteurs. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The group SABALI comprises six women, all married and averaging 39 years of age and four children each. The women live in traditional extended families with their husbands, co-wives, brothers, and sons in the Hérémakono Nord district of Bougouni City. They know one another through ties of community, friendship, and commerce. To bolster their financial capacity, so as to operate their businesses better, they joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second loan. The previous loan was indeed paid back. 

This group of women does commerce in grains, as does AWA, who is the first women on the left in the photo. She buys and sells grains and intends to use her loan to purchase 2 tonnes of corn from peasant producers. Accepting cash or credit, she makes her sales at the market and at home to a customer base composed essentially of women. She envisions making an average monthly profit of 35,000 francs CFA that will be reinvested in her work and used to repay the loan.

loans.use: to purchase corn

loans.name: Matlab

texts.en:
A kind man by the name of Matlab lives in a house which is in disrepair. His wife is a lovely woman who is housewife and does not earn an income. They have 3 clever children of 10, 8 and 5 years old. Matlab’s children want to live in the house which is nice but his income from animal husbandry is not enough to repair it. He must repair all the rooms in his old house. He lives in the country and the weather is very cold in the winter, that’s why his house must be comfortable. He is asking for a loan of 700 USD to buy building materials such as cement, wood and etc. to repair his house.
In this way he will be able to offer his family a better quality of life and moral stability that will allow them to progress in life. Each month he will make his payment on time. He awaits your support and mercy.

loans.use: to buy building materials such as wood and cement to repair his house.

loans.name: Josphine

texts.en:
Josphine is a 37-year-old tailor in Bamburi Mombasa. She owns a tailoring shop and a motorcycle for her transportation business. She is a married mother of three whose husband earns additional income, and she has done well the last nine years with these businesses.
This marks her third time borrowing from KADET LTD, to purchase more fabric for her shop and an additional sewing machine.
She will use the anticipated profit to pay back her loan and continue expanding both her businesses. She hopes to be a successful business lady in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more fabric for her shop and an additional sewing machine.

loans.name: Harutiun

texts.en:
Harutiun is 29 years old. He lives in the Akhalkalaki District with his wife, two children and parents, who are provided with a retirement pension. Harutiun requested loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, without any success. His loan request was rejected, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions.

The only source of income is a small monthly salary earned by Harutiun’s wife working as a teacher at a local school. It is hardly enough to provide food for the family. According to Credo estimations the family belongs to the subsistence poor category.

Harutiun requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. Harutiun has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provisions of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With his credit Harutiun will purchase a car. After purchasing a car, he plans to serve local people as a taxi driver and earn an income. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase a car and work as a taxi driver.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe   DANAYA  est constitué de 5 femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 29 ans et 03 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier  Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur deuxième prêt. Le précédent prêt à été correctement remboursé. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de pagnes et de tissus à l’image de HABI,qui est la seule femme arrêtée dans la photo. Elle fait l’achat vente de tissus et compte acheter avec son  prêt, 25 pagnes wax avec les grossistes de Bamako. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The group DANAYA comprises five married women averaging 29 years of age and three children each. The women live in traditional extended families in the Hérémakono Nord district of Bougouni City. They know one another through ties of community, friendship, and commerce. To bolster their financial capacity, so as to operate their businesses better, they joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second loan. The previous loan was correctly paid back.

This group of women does commerce in 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa) and fabrics, as does HABI, who is the only women standing in the photo. She buys and sells fabrics and intends to use her loan to purchase 25 lengths of Wax 'pagne' from Bamako wholesalers. Accepting cash or credit, she makes her sales retail at the market and at home to a customer base composed essentially of women. She envisions making an average monthly profit of 22,000 francs CFA that will be reinvested in her work and used to repay the loan.

loans.use: to purchase 'pagne' cloth

loans.name: Agapita

texts.en: Agapita is 45 years old, married with 41 children. She lives in Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She owns and operates a retail business to earn a living. She has been in her business for over 5 years and earns 2,000 PHP every month. She joined GDMPC in 2010, and now she has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional shampoo, soap, sugar and coffee to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional shampoo, soap, sugar and coffee to sell.

loans.name: Faida Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe FAIDA est constitué de 4 femmes mariées et  1 célibataire ayant une moyenne d’âge de 23 ans et 2 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier  Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles  adhérent à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur premier prêt. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de  céréales à l’image de LALA ,qui est la première femme de la gauche vers la droite. Elle fait l’achat vente de  céréales et compte acheter avec son  prêt, 500 Kg de riz paddy  avec les paysans producteurs de  Bougouni. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The group FAIDA comprises four married women and one unmarried. They average 23 years of age and two children each, and they live in traditional extended families in the Hérémakono Nord district of Bougouni City. They know one another through ties of community, friendship, and commerce. To bolster their financial capacity, so as to operate their businesses better, they joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first loan. 

This group of women does commerce in grains, as does LALA, who is the first women on the left in the photo. She buys and sells grains and intends to use her loan to purchase 500 kg of rice from peasant producers of Bougouni. Accepting cash or credit, she makes her sales retail at the market and at home to a customer base composed essentially of women. She envisions making an average monthly profit of 15,000 francs CFA that will be reinvested in her work and used to repay the loan.

loans.use: to purchase rice

loans.name: Sayriddin

texts.en:
A hardworking man by the name of Sayriddin lives with his family far from the center of the city in a house which is in disrepair. He is 32 years old. He is married and has 2 children who are 5 and 3 years old. His wife is housewife and she has been busy with the upbringing of their children. Sayriddin is a master carpenter. All the people of his village know him as a good carpenter. Sayriddin builds very wonderful buildings with modern planning. He is the only one working in the family. He does not have the money to repair his house, as his house is very old. He is asking for a loan of 350 USD to buy building materials such as wood and cement for repairing his house.
In this way he will be able to offer his family a better quality of life and moral stability that will allow them to progress. Each month he will make his payment on time. He awaits your support and mercy.

loans.use: to buy building materials such as wood and cement for repairing his house.

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana is 46 years old, married with six children, two of whom are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.
Feliciana has a food vending business in the Philippines. Feliciana requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food vending business.
Feliciana has been in this business for 23 years. In the future, Feliciana would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food vending business.

loans.name: Tamaz

texts.en:
Tamaz is 61 years old. He lives in Kianeti village, Bolnisi District with his 59-year-old wife Nanuli.  Tamaz requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time, because of low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The main source of the income for the family is from agricultural activities. In particular, they own a plot of land and a vineyard. Tamaz cultivates the land and plants different kinds of fruit and vegetables. Harvested grapes are used to make vodka and wine. They are sold with the harvested fruits and vegetables at the local markets. The family also has a pig and four piglets. Nanuli is looking after them. Later when piglets are grown they will be sold as meat.

Tamaz requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. Tamaz has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit Tamaz will purchase two milk cows. They will be milking the cows every day and making dairy products. The products will be sold at the local markets and among the villagers so the family will be able to earn a good profit. Part of the profit will be used for reinvesting in the same field, in order to expand their agricultural business and another part for covering their monthly expenses. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva Start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: To purchase two milk cows

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
This marks Susan's third loan. After servicing her second loan successfully, she has since expanded her business and employed one more person to help her in her shop. She hopes to continue growing her business.

Susan plans to purchase sewing thread and fabrics and materials for making clothing for her customers.

loans.use: to purchase sewing thread and materials for making clothing

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is married and has six children, five of whom are still in school. They live in Kisii. He has been a farmer for twenty three years producing and selling bananas, maize, milk, and beans. He currently runs his farm with the help of one farmhand.

He has requested a loan from Juhudi Kilimo of KES. 62,400 to purchase and insure a dairy cow, in order to increase his milk production. This will improve his family's income and hence help his family to have an adequate supply of food. He expects a high yield and an improved level of milk production. Lack of a local market and lack of storage facilities are the major problems he is encountering.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow to increase milk production.

loans.name: Tusaidiane Group

texts.fr: La cliente Cihonzi est trésorière du groupe Tusaidiane, entrepreneur dynamique, âgée de 53 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Son conjoint est un chômeur.  La cliente est vendeuse des denrées alimentaires. Depuis son jeune âge, elle exerce cette activité. Elle expose ses produits au marché central de Kadutu. Parmi ses 5 enfants, il ya des majeurs, qui ont déjà leurs familles. Ce nouveau prêt va lui servir d’acheter de farine de manioc, les patates douces, les légumes, les fruits, etc. Elle souhaite agrandir son entreprise et construire un grand entrepôt agricole. Au finish, elle remercie Hekima pour son soutien en microcrédit.
texts.en:
This client, Cihonzi, is the treasurer of the group Tusaidiane. An energetic entrepreneur, she is 53 years old, married, and the mother of five children. Her husband is unemployed. This client sells grocery items. She has been in this business since she was young. She displays her products at the central market of Kadutu. Among her five children, some are adults with their own families already. 

This new loan is going to be used to purchase cassava flour, sweet potatoes, fruit & vegetables, etc. She would like to expand her enterprise and build a large agricultural warehouse. In conclusion, she thanks Hekima for it micro-loan support.

loans.use: to purchase cassava flour, sweet potatoes, fruit & vegetables, etc.

loans.name: Serema

texts.en:
Serena is a married man with school going children. He owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for his family and school fees.
For the past three years, he has operated a business of buying and selling livestock, selling at the market to his local neighbors. He faces a major challenge of seasonality and a high cost of transportation in his place of operation.
With the loan that he is requesting, he wants to purchase goats and sheep for raise for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase goats and sheep to raise for resale.

loans.name: 04-06-05-Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Ms. Tú has a retail business selling dry food. She is requesting a loan to purchase candy and biscuits to resell and purchase cloth to do tailoring.

Tú is 44 years old and she is single with two children. Tú is the group leader of the 04-06-05-Nam Ngạn solidarity group, which consists of eight members.
