Her hopes and dreams are to have a better future and improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and tires

loans.name: Bernardina

texts.en:
Bernardina is 53 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by fattening pigs in the Philippines. Bernardina is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs. She has been pig fattening for four years and also earns additional income from direct selling of Avon products.

Bernardina is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon is 49 years old and married with seven children. She works hard to provide for her family. Corazon runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to re-stock her store with food and household goods like soap, canned goods, snack foods, and noodles to sell.

Corazon has borrowed and paid eight loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from rice retailing.

Corazon aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to re-stock her store with food and household goods like soap, canned goods, snack foods, and noodles

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
This is Arlene. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more products for her variety store, thus generating more income. The loan also helped with her children's education and in her family's household expenses. Arlene has had this business for 12 years now. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday expenses.

Arlene would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Arlene dreams that her children will finish their studies, and she hopes for continuous growth in her business. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and it is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add to her inventory

loans.name: Jeanlie

texts.en:
Jeanlie is a 34-year-old married woman from Ubay, Bohol. She is a mother of 6 children. The oldest child is 16 while the youngest is 4.

She operates a sari-sari (variety) store. She sells items such as sugar, noodles, soaps, shampoo and beverages. Her husband works as a collector in a private company. His income is very meager to sustain the daily needs of the family.

Jeanlie requested a loan of 6,000 PHP to buy additional stock like canned goods, assorted soft drinks and vegetables. In the future Jeanlie would like to expand her business to support her family as well as to finance her children's education.

loans.use: to buy additional stock like canned goods,  assorted soft drinks and vegetables

loans.name: Aurita

texts.en:
This is Aurita. Her previous loan was a big help for her business. She was able to buy and sell more ready-to-wear products and she was able to generate more income. She has been in this business for six years now. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan for her to buy additional stock of ready-to-wear products like clothes for men and women. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Aurita dreams to have her own stall easily seen by people and hopes to have their own house. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional inventory such as ready-to-wear men's and women's clothes

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is from the village of Aurora, Alicia. She is 34 years old and is happily married to Federico. The couple had been blessed with three children.

To raise her children, Yolanda is engaged in a retailing business. She has been in this business for 11 years. She wanted to build-up her business so, to make it possible, Yolanda is requesting a loan in the amount of 50,000 PHP to buy condiments, beverage, curls (cheese-flavored puffed snacks), assorted bread and school supplies. Yolanda hopes that she can obtain her desired loan and she hopes to continue to grow her business.

loans.use: to buy condiments, beverage, curls, assorted bread and school supplies

loans.name: Jempiring Group

texts.en:
The Jempiring group is a new pig farmer group with 10 members that are requesting a loan in the amount of 20 million IDR. They joined together as a group to get funding and training from MUK. They received information about MUK and their pig groups from an existing group in another village.
Ni Wayan is 23 years old, a housewife, and she has 1 child. Her husband works as a farmer. In addition to helping her husband as a farmer, Ni Wayan is pursuing efforts raise pigs. With the loan she will buy two piglets for fattening and feed for them. She plans to sell the piglets. Ni Wayan hopes to be able to fix her house with the profits from raising pigs.

loans.use: to purchase 2 piglets and feed for them.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
This is Lourdes. She previously accessed a 15,000 PHP loan that she used to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. Her earnings were a big help in their personal, house hold and business expenditures.
She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan for her to purchase raw ingredients and supplies needed in her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.
Lourdes dreams to have more loyal customers. She meets with her co-fellowship members* every week, to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for raw ingredients like rice, pork, chicken and vegetables and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Rona

texts.en:
This is Rona, 22, a resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines. Her partner is a vendor and they have children. She and her partner are working to provide income for their everyday expenses.

Rona operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHPs-worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

She is requesting a 9,000 PHP loan to help her continue in the operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

Rona dreams to have a bigger stall and hopes to give her children a good education and life.  She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida is a 55-year-old married woman from Ubay, Bohol. She has 12 children. The oldest child is 38 while the youngest is 16 years old respectively. 

Leonida owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store. She sells items like vinegar, biscuits, noodles, beverages and soaps. She requested a loan of 12,000 PHP to buy more stock like canned goods, shampoo, detergents, soft drinks and condiments to cater to the needs of the customer.

In the future, Leonida would like to expand her business to support her family as well as to finance her children's college education.

loans.use: to buy more stock like canned goods, shampoo, detergents, soft drinks  and condiments

loans.name: Ankhbayar

texts.en: Mr. Ankhbayar is 27 years old, and lives with his wife, two children and parents-in-law in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family resides in their own house on fenced land. His wife works as a cashier at a grocery store. His mother-in-law has retired from work and gets a state pension. His father-in-law prepares harvests wood. He himself has been rendering taxi services to local people for two consecutive years and accumulated enough experience to pick good customers, know the shortcut roads and carry his customers quickly to their destination. The house they live in has been deteriorated over the years and needs some serious repair. As you can see in his photo, the house has very vulnerable windows, roof and walls and during the harsh winter time, the family is cold down to their cores and in order to not freeze in their house, they burn lots of coal for heating. He is requesting a loan of 4,000,000 MNT to purchase building and insulation materials such as bricks, metals, fiberglass, foam and planks. Using those materials, he can repair and insulate his house. The renovated house will certainly enable the family to live in a warm and comfortable place as well as burn less coal, emit less smoke and contribute to the efforts against air pollution. The borrower is a very hardworking individual who strives for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase building and insulation materials to repair his house.

loans.name: Jelly

texts.en:
Jelly is a 31-year-old married woman who has worked as a tailor for three years. She enjoys her business. She has been able to raise her children with the income she generates from her tailoring business. Jelly plans to have her own tailoring shop someday in order to display all of her sample curtains and pillow cases. Currently, she brings her samples to the market to encourage sales. She is highly motivated to improve her enterprise in order to increase her income. 

Jelly is now requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to buy garments to make curtains and pillow cases. She hopes to make her dreams come true through her hard work and patience in managing her businesses.

loans.use: to buy garments to make curtains and pillow cases

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
This is Yolanda, 54, a resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines. She is married to Pedro and is a mother. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Yolanda operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that sells groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and reselling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, Yolanda is requesting a PHP 17,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Yolanda dreams that her business will be stable and hopes that her children and grandchildren will have a better living. She meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries, and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is a 56-year-old married woman from Ubay, Bohol. She has five grown children. Marilyn operates a machine and welding shop. She accepts work like repair of electrical motor shafts, various welding jobs, and other machine-related work. She has been operating a welding shop for 23 years. 

Marilyn requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to buy a new welding machine to enhance her business operations and to cater to the needs of her customers. In the future, she would like to expand her business to support her family as well as to save for old age.

loans.use: to buy a new welding machine

loans.name: Anie

texts.en:
This is Anie, 54, a resident of Malibay, Pasay, Philippines. She is married to Pedro and is a mother.  She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Anie operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most families only eat home-cooked meals during the evenings when all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a usual family tradition, but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands costs less than raw food. Anie's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, Anie is requesting a loan of PHP 15, 000. She will use the loan to buy more raw ingredients like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments, and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Anie dreams that her business will continue to grow and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets with her co-fellowship members every week to share stories of her life and business and also to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God, which she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients like rice, pork, chicken, and vegetables, and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 52 years old, married with two children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Mary has a business selling dry goods in the Philippines. Mary requested a loan of PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy more dry goods to sell.

Mary has been in this business for five years. In the future, Mary would like to save money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to buy more dry goods to sell.

loans.name: Ponciana

texts.en: Ponciana earns a living through selling her coconut wine, known locally as tuba. She has been in the business for more than 25 years now. Coconut can also be fermented into a coconut vinegar. Ponciana is asking for a loan to buy more coconut juice/wine and containers. With this, she will be able to sell more and earn more profit.

loans.use: to buy more coconut juice/wine and containers

loans.name: Zarah

texts.en:
This is Zarah. She previously accessed a loan of 40,000 PHP that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another loan of 40,000 PHP to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Zarah dreams for a continuous growth in her business and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies there.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn is 52 years old and married with four children, two of whom are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Merlyn has a food production business in the Philippines. Merlyn requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients and utensils for her food production business.

Merlyn has been in this business for twenty-one years. In the future, Merlyn would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients and utensils for her food production business.

loans.name: Reylen

texts.en:
Reylen is 47 years old and married with two children. She works hard to provide for her family. Reylen runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 23,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell.

Reylen has borrowed and repaid 23 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 20 years and she earns additional income from food vending. Reylen aspires to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Marieta

texts.en:
This is Marietta. She previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread, and other materials needed in her bridal gown rental business. Her earnings were a big help in covering her personal, household, and business expenses.

Marietta would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan in order to buy additional supplies of raw materials needed in her business. The profits from her business will definitely help her meet her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Marieta hopes to have more stalls and dreams that her children will have a good future. She meets up with her co-fellowship members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and from the Word of God, which she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for cloth, fabric, thread and other materials needed in making a gown.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn is a 33-year-old married woman from Ubay, Bohol. She has two children. Her younger child is 9 and the older one is 12. Her work is to provide services like manicures and pedicures. She has been in the manicure and pedicure business for six years. 

Merlyn requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to buy materials like scrubs, nail polish, acetone, and toe separators. In the future, she would like to expand her business to support her family as well as to save for her children's education.

loans.use: to buy materials like scrubs, nail polish, acetone, and toe separators

loans.name: Albina

texts.en:
This is Albina. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more supplies and products needed in her business. She has had this business for ten years now. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for another 30,000 PHP loan to buy different products like belts, towels, umbrellas, flashlights, hammers and other products needed in her general merchandise store. The profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Albina dreams that her business will continue to grow and hopes that her children will continue their studies. She meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and products needed in her home products business.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda operates her three hectares of rice farm land and her livestock business (hog raising and fishpond). It's been 30 years since she started cultivating her rice farm land. She is indeed grateful because through her dedication and wise management, she was able to obtain better yields last season.

Nilda is 48 years old and happily married to a farmer. The couple were blessed with three children. Her eldest is a nursing graduate while the other two still go to school. She aims to support them until they finish their degree courses. For her goal to be realized, she is seeking additional capital of PHP 40,000 which will be used to buy 14 sacks of fertilizer, four litres of insecticides and four sacks of seedlings for her rice farming business. She knows that this loan will have a great impact in making her rice field productive. Nilda hopes that this amount of loan will be granted.

loans.use: to buy 14 sacks of fertilizer, four litres of insecticides and four sacks of seedlings for her rice farming business

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is a 49-year-old married woman and a mother of three children. She is from Panglao, Bohol. She has been engaged in food vending and hog raising businesses for more than 11 years now. This has been her main source of income.

Mary Jane is asking for a loan to buy ingredients for food vending like flour, sugar, butter, and cooking oil and to purchase feed for her pigs. With this loan, she will be able to improve her business and earnings. In the future, Mary Jane hopes to expand her business and make it a success.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for food vending like flour, sugar, butter, and cooking oil and to purchase feed for her pigs

loans.name: Lea

texts.en:
This is Lea. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more products for her variety store. The loan also helped in the education of her children and in their household expenditures. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday needs. 

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. The profits from her business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Lea dreams that her business will continue to grow and hopes to grow her relationship with God as well. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed for her business.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
La señora Mercedes tiene ya mas de 32 años radicando en la ciudad de Nuevo Laredo, es originaria de la ciudad de San Luis Potosí, tiene65 años de edad y es una persona trabajadora e independiente.
Esta solicitando un préstamo para invertir en compra de mercancía de temporada de verano ya que le están solicitando sus clientes que tenga esta tipo de mercancía para vender, pero no cuenta con el dinero necesario para invertir en su negocio.
Desea realizar la inversión a su negocio y así tendrá más ganancias ya que vive sola, porque sus hijos tienen su propia familia.
Con las ganancias que obtiene de las ventas será para pagar el crédito y que sus hijos le ayudan económicamente con los gastos.
texts.en:
Mercedes has already spent more than 32 years in the city of Nuevo Laredo but she is originally from the city of San Luis Potosí. She is 65 years old and is a hardworking and independent person. 
She is requesting a loan to buy goods for the summer season as her clients are requesting them but she doesn't have the capital that she needs to invest in her business. 
She wants to make the investment in her business and, as a result, she will have better income as she lives alone because her children have their own families. 
With the profits that she makes from her sales, she will make her repayments and help her children financially.

loans.use: to buy merchandise.

loans.name: Edith Del Carmen

texts.es: Doña edith vive en casa propia con su esposo y sus 2 hijos tiene un negocio de pasteleria desde hace varios años elabora pasteles para bodas, cumpleaños, quinceaños, etc. tiene mucha clientela pues los da ha buen precio; su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su lugar de residencia, Doña Edith solicita un credito que le permita comprar productos como: harina, colorantes comestibles, crema pastelera, y todo lo necesario para poder seguir con su negocio y poder seguirle dando a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Edith lives in her own home with her husband and their 2 children. She has a business making cakes and she has been working for some years baking cakes for weddings, birthdays, coming of age celebrations, etc. She has many customers and she gives them a good price. Her business is located in her home. Edith is requesting a loan that will enable her to buy goods such as: flour, food coloring, confectioners custard, and everything that is needed to make her business run and for her to be able to continue giving her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy materials for her cake baking business.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is a married woman from Panglao on Bohol Island in the Philippines. She has a food vending business selling home-cooked foods to people in her community. Evelyn is asking for a loan to buy more ingredients for her business, such as sweet potato, banana, flour, cooking oil and sugar. With this, she will be able to cook and sell more snack foods, thus increasing her profits. Evelyn dreams of a better life in the future together with her family.

loans.use: to buy more ingredients for her business, such as sweet potato, banana, flour, cooking oil and sugar

loans.name: Myra

texts.en: This sari-sari store has been Myra’s business for the past four years. She sells commodities like sugar, vinegar, cooking oil, salt, rice, milk and junk foods. She is being focused on her business because this is her only way to help her husband to support her children. As time passes by, their necessities are growing. Now, she is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP to buy soft drinks, breads, and condiments such as vinegar, soy sauce and cooking oil as additional merchandise to offer. She hopes to gain more through these goods for her to provide for the needs of her three children.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, breads and condiments such as vinegar, soy sauce and cooking oil

loans.name: Cristy

texts.en:
Cristy is 44 years-old and married with five children.

Cristy works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 20,000 loan through Kiva partner NWTF in order to purchase more stock to sell.

Cristy has borrowed and repaid 20 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for ten years and also earns an income from fishing.

Cristy aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Josephine is married and is a responsible mother of three children. She is 43 years of age and she manages a hog fattening business. Currently, she is asking for a loan of P8,000 in order to buy additional feed,  vitamins and medicines for her pigs. This will be great help to make her pigs healthier and fatter. She hopes to expand her business and make a good profit to save for the future of her three children.

loans.use: to buy additional feed,  vitamins and medicines for her pigs.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 43 years-old and married with two children, one of whom is in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Teresita has a tailoring business in the Philippines. Teresita has requested a PHP 16,000 loan amount through Kiva partner NWTF in order to buy tailoring supplies.

Teresita has been in this business for ten years. In the future, Teresita would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy tailoring supplies.

loans.name: Ronora

texts.en:
Ronora is 34 years-old and married with two children, both of her children are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Ronora has a fishing business in the Philippines. Ronora requested a PHP 12,000 loan through Kiva partner NWTF in order to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

Ronora has been in this business for nine years. In the future, Ronora would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

loans.name: Alvaro Martin

texts.es:
Alvaro es n joven de 28 años de edad, es padre de una pequeña de 6 añitos a la cual quiere muchísimo y por la cual se esfuerza mucho para darle una vida digna. La vivienda de Alvaro se encuentra en la ciudad de Pisco, ciudad ubicada en la costa Sur del Perú y en la cual podemos encontrar playas hermosas y sus pobladores son personas amables y alegres.

Cada día Alvaro trabaja como empleado en un pequeño restaurante de su ciudad, el labora alrededor de 9 horas al día y el cree que está saliendo adelante con su negocio porque es responsable y honrado.

Alvaro está muy agradecido con los prestamistas kiva ya que gracias a su gran apoyo el podrá comprar un computadora ya que las clases de su universidad están por empezar y le es necesario contar con esta herramienta para poder elaborar sus trabajos, asi el seguirá luchando por hacer realidad su más grande sueño:” Tener una carrera profesional y su negocio propio”.
texts.en:
Alvaro is a young man of 28 years old. He is father to a little girl of 6 years old who he loves very much and for whom he strives hard to give her a dignified life. Alvaro's house is in the city of Pisco, which is located on the south coast of Peru and it's a place where you can find beautiful beaches and people who are kind and cheerful. 
Everyday, Alvaro works as an employee in a little restaurant in the city. He works around 9 hours a day and he believes he is getting ahead at work because he is responsible and honorable. 
Alvaro is very grateful to the Kiva lenders and, thanks to their great support, he will be able to buy a computer which he needs because the classes at his university are about to start and he needs to have this technology to be able to do his work. In this way he will continue working to make his greatest dream come true: to have a professional career and his own business.

loans.use: to buy a computer.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She lives in her own house, which has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over two years, she has operated a poultry farming business, rearing broilers and layers, which she sells from home to her neighbors and restaurant operators. In addition, she also owns rental houses, which provide her other source of income. She says that her challenge is disease outbreak, which causes losses. Esther dreams of expanding her business to a wholesale one to earn more income.

With the Kshs 25,000 she wants to purchase chicks and chicken feed. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and chicken feed.

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en: Carolina, 63 years-old, is a widow with six adult children. Carolina has managed a rice and corn store in their village for almost 53 years. In this business she's earning a net income of Php 4,000 per week. She would like to have a loan of 30,000 PHP in order to purchase rice and corn to sell. She's hoping that her requested loan will be granted so that she can establish a profitable business.

loans.use: to purchase rice and corn to sell.

loans.name: Latifa

texts.en:
Latifa  is 57 years-old. She has grown vegetables and fruit for more than 20 years. She is very hard-working and passionate about her work .She considers it fun to grow potatoes, tomatoes, cucumbers and to plant  fruit trees with her husband. She sells her crops in the bazaar in order to make profits to support her family.

Latifa's income from this business is 150 AZN. In order to increase the standard of living of her family she plans to expand her business.

She has already taken three loans from Aqroinvest in the past. With a good loan history, she has applied for a third loan of 2000 AZN. With this money she wants to invest in the business and buy more fruit trees in order to generate more revenue.

loans.use: to invest in the business by buying more fruit trees.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia is a 59 year-old married woman from Ubay, Bohol.  She has eight adult children. She operates a retail store business. She sells items such as vinegar, sugar, canned goods, noodles, soaps and soft drinks.  Her husband is a farmer. 

She has requested a loan of 8,000 PHP in order to buy additional groceries and soft drinks to avoid shortages and also to cater to the needs of her customers. In the future, Patricia would like to expand her business in order to support her family as well as to save for the old age.

loans.use: to buy additional groceries and soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Agnetta

texts.en: Agnetta is taking out another Kiva loan to expand her existing charcoal-selling business. With the loan, she wants to purchase 10 sacks of charcoal for resale. Agnetta is grateful of the opportunity given by Yehu Microfinance and Kiva lenders to access loans.

loans.use: to purchase 10 sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is a hard-working mother and of full of hope. She is married with two children. She is thankful because she has been running her retail store for four years.

Erlinda would like to increase the volume of grocery items she offers within her local community, but she doesn't have enough capital. She is asking for a loan of PHP25,000 to buy cases of soft drinks, canned goods, assorted biscuits and junk food for her retail store. She believes that with more grocery items she could earn a better profit, improve her financial stability and satisfy her customers' demand. Erlinda hopes for the approval of her requested loan.

loans.use: to buy cases of soft drinks, canned goods, assorted biscuits and junk food for her retail store

loans.name: Coralia Elissette

texts.es:
Coralia, se dedica a la elaboración y venta de tortillas. Ella vive con su familia, su compañero de vida y sus hijos los cuales tienen edades de 3 y 4 años de edad, dependen tres económicamente; el negocio lo aprendió de familia, lo realiza de 6:00 am a 6:00 pm, ya que lo lleva a cabo en su casa y hasta el momento no ha tenido ninguna dificultad.
El préstamo que requiere lo invertirá en la compra maíz, gas propano y todo lo necesario para la producción  de tortillas; esta inversión le ayudara a incrementar sus ventas y tener inventario para estar preparada para los días que llueve.
Su sueño es poder realizar mejoras a la vivienda y darle una mayor calidad de vida a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Coralia works making and selling tortillas. She lives with her family, her partner and children who are 3 and 4 years old and economically dependent. She learned her work from her family. She works from 6:00am until 6:00pm and works from home and to date she has not had any difficulties. 
She will use the loan that she is requesting to buy corn, propane gas, and everything that is needed for making tortillas. This investment will help her to increase her sales and have inventory so that she is prepared for rainy days. 
Her dream is to be able to make improvements to her house and give a better quality of life to her children.

loans.use: to buy corn, propane gas, and everything necessary to make tortillas.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is a 31-year-old married woman from Ubay, Bohol. She has 4 children. The oldest child is 8 years old while the youngest is 7 months old. She raises pigs. She has been raising pigs for 3 years. Her husband works in a private company. His income is not enough for the family's daily needs.

Yolanda requested a loan of 9,000 PHP to buy feeds and pig supplements for the pigs to grow healthy and strong so she will be able to sell them on time. In the future Yolanda would like to expand her piggery business to support her family as well as to finance her children's education.

loans.use: to buy feeds and pig supplements.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
This is Virginia, 46, a resident of Intramuros, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Leonardo and a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Virginia operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families eat home-cooked meals only during the evening when all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a typical family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one or two persons when buying cooked rice and viands cost less than raw food. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Virginia hopes that her business will grow and expand even more and dreams that her children will have their own businesses. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients like rice, pork, chicken, vegetables and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Franco Abel

texts.es:
Franco es un joven d e20 años de edad es muy alegre y entusiasta y sobre todo trabajador, el labora como empleado en un supermercado de su ciudad, y con el fruto de su trabajo solventa sus estudios en la universidad con mucho esfuerzo. Franco trabaja alrededor de 1 horas al día y en las noches acude a su centro de estudios, a pesar del cansancio que pueda sentir debido a lo arduo de su dia, Franco se sacrifica mucho por seguir estudiando y podrá apoyar a su familia, por ello el cree que esta saliendo adelante por lo dedicado y responsable que es.

Franco está muy agradecido con los prestamistas Kiva ya que gracias a la ayuda que le han brindado podrá pagar la inscripción a su nuevo ciclo de estudios, asi como la mensualidad y gastos de útiles, de esta manera el podrá seguir esforzándose por ser un gran profesional y hacer realidad su más grane sueño:” Terminar su carrera y tener un negocio propio”.
texts.en:
Franco is a young man who is 20 years old and very cheerful and enthusiastic and, above all, hardworking. He works as an employee in a supermarket in his city and, with the fruit of his labors, he pays for his studies at the university, which he puts a lot of effort into. Franco works around 10 hours a day and in the evenings he goes to his place of study despite the tiredness that he can feel due to his hard day. Franco makes sacrifices to be able to keep studying and to be able to support his family and he believes that he is doing well because of his dedication and responsibility. 
Franco is very grateful to the Kiva lenders as, thanks to the help that they have offered him, he will be able to pay the enrollment fee for his new course of studies as well as monthly fees and utilities. In this way he will be able to keep striving to be a good professional and make his greatest dream come true: to finish his degree and have his own business.

loans.use: to pay enrollment and months fees.

loans.name: Dúo Luchadoras De Sacatepequez Group

texts.es:
DÚO LUCHADORAS DE SACATEPEQUEZ
Este grupo es integrada por las señora Hermenegilda de 49 años de edad quien desde hace mas de 15 años se ha dedicado al comercio, como venta de  tortillas, venta de pollo, y ahora  ha iniciado con la venta de refacciones los fines de  semana en su domicilio, doña Hermenegilda  con su deseo de luchar para sacar adelante a  su hija quien estudia  nivel diversificado, su deseo es ver graduada a su hija y prepararse para el futuro,esta solicitando este credito para la compra de maiz y carne de pollo para la venta.
texts.en:
DÚO LUCHADORAS DE SACATEPEQUEZ

This group is integrated by Señora Hermenegilda who is 49 years old. For more than 15 years she has worked in business, selling tortillas, chicken, and she has now started to sell snacks at the weekend from her home. Doña Hermenegilda, with her desire to fight to get her daughter ahead, who is studying at high school, and her wish to see her daughter graduate and prepare herself for the future, is asking for this loan to buy corn and chicken to sell.

loans.use: to buy corn and chicken to sell.

loans.name: Ana Guadalupe

texts.es:
Ana, solicita un nuevo préstamo para fortalecer el negocio de venta de comida y así generar más ingresos; ya el financiamiento de los créditos son una fuente favorable;  este le ayudara a comprar verduras, arroz, azúcar, sal, maíz, entre otros productos. 
El crédito anterior le permitió adquirir mejores ganancias, ya que tienen una mejor calidad de vida y sus hijos siguen estudiando.
texts.en:
Ana is requesting a new loan in order to strengthen her business of food sales and thereby generate more income. The financing from loans is a favorable source. This will help her to buy vegetables, rice, sugar, salt, and corn, among other things.

The previous loan allowed her to obtain better profits, and they now have a better quality of life and her children are continuing with their studies.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, rice, sugar, salt, and corn, among other things

loans.name: Robin

texts.en:
Robin is a 47-year-old married man from a small village near Jenin. He is a father with two sons and two daughters. He has worked as a taxi driver for six years and his wife works as an employee to help her husband with the family expenses.
 
Robin took a 1,500 USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to cover the costs of yearly maintenance and make some improvements to his taxi. By taking this loan, the taxi capacity will increase so the family income will increase, too.

Robin is photographed in front of his taxi.

loans.use: to pay the costs of yearly maintenance for his taxi.

loans.name: Duaa

texts.en:
Duaa is a conservative person who prefers not to have her photo published online, so her husband appears in her Kiva profile photo, pictured in their new house.

Duaa is a married woman from Qalqilia. She is a mother of three sons and one daughter. Her husband is a worker with a very low wage which barely covers the family's needs. She and her husband would like to complete their new house to improve the family's living conditions. 

She requested a 2,000 USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help Duaa and her husband complete building their new house. The family will live in better conditions.

loans.use: to pay the costs of completing the family house.

loans.name: Petra

texts.en:
This is Petra. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more grocery items for her variety store, thus generating more income. The loan also helped in the education of her children and in their household expenditures. This has been her business for four years now. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday expenses.

She would like to apply for another 14,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and the children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Petra dreams that her business will continue to be successful and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages for her business.

loans.name: Carlos Ernesto

texts.es:
Carlos, se dedica a la venta de medicina orgánica y natural. El está acompañado, tiene un hijo de 8 años de edad y todos dependen de él, no reciben ayuda del extranjero; el oficio lo realiza en su propio local y distribuye el producto en lugares cercanos del mercado.
El préstamo que requiere lo invertirá en la compra de mercadería, variedad de velas, agua floridad, alcohol, entre otros  para ofrecerles a los clientes diversidad de productos; esto le ayudara a aumentar su capacidad económica   y mejorar la calidad de vida.
Su sueño es tener su propia casa.
texts.en:
Carlos makes a living selling organic and natural medicines.  He is married, has one child who is eight years old, and they all depend on him; they do not receive help from abroad.  He does the work in his own town and distributes the product in nearby places in the market.

The loan that he needs will be invested in the purchase of merchandise; a variety of candles, scented water, and alcohol, among others, so that he can offer his customers a diversity of products.  This will help him to increase his financial abilities and improve his quality of life.  His dream is to have his own house.

loans.use: to buy merchandise; a variety of candles, scented water, and alcohol, among others.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en: Estrella is a 45-year-old married woman and a mother of 2 children from Panglao, Bohol. She has been engaged in a hog raising business for more than 3 years now. This is the source of her income. She is asking for a loan to buy additional piglets to raise and feeds for the pigs. With this, she will be able to improve her business and make it a success.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets to raise and feeds for the pigs.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is coming to Yehu for another Kiva loan to boost his vegetable selling business. With the loan he wants to purchase sacks of vegetables for resale. The previous loan had a great impact on his business which enabled him to double his monthly profits. He is grateful for the opportunity given by Yehu and Kiva lenders for the opportunity given.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Mishi

texts.en:
Mishi is a married mother of three children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, she has operated a fish selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. Her goal is to establish a restaurant business in the near future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase a stock of fish for resale. She decided to join Yehu because of the variety of loan products available for clientele.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of fish for resale.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a widow with five children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is household items.

For over three years, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling from home to her local residents. She faces the challenge of seasonality in her business. Rose dreams of establishing a greengrocery business in the near future.  

With the Kshs 15,000 she wants to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes, onions and potatoes.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes, onions and potatoes.

loans.name: Mushtaq

texts.en:
Mushtaq owns a gift shop in the main market of Lahore, Pakistan. He sells a variety of souvenirs and gift items in his shop. He is a responsible father of one child. He is a very caring husband and father. 

He would like to buy a variety of pieces for his shop, however, he does not have enough savings to purchase the products. Therefore he has requested a loan of 100,000 pkr from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan. This will help him to provide more variety to his clients and to increase his net income as well.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of souvenirs and gift items for the shop.

loans.name: Mia

texts.en:
This is Mia. She previously accessed a 22,000 PHP loan that she used buy more quantities of products and ingredients. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 10,000 PHP loan for her to purchase bananas, sugar, charcoal, oil and other ingredients for her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Mia hopes that her business will continue to grow and dreams that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for bananas, sugar, charcoal, oil and other ingredients for her business.

loans.name: Kavumbi

texts.en:
Kavumbi is a widow with seven children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and household items.

For over three years, Kavumbi has operated a charcoal-selling businesss. She sells from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a challenge of the high cost of transportation. Her dream is to become a wholesale supplier of charcoal in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase 10 sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu because of the availability of products that meet clientele needs.

loans.use: to purchase 10 sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 47 years old and married with 4 children, two of whom are in school. Lucy works very hard to provide for them. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell.

She has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items such as sardines, snack foods and other groceries. In the future Lucy would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Marlina

texts.en:
Marlina is 37 years old and single. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

She has been in this business for five years and has previously received funds through Kiva. Marlina aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina is 53 years old, married and has two children.  

Catalina is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She has been raising pigs for six years now, and has borrowed four times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

Catalina requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz is 60 years old and widowed. She has three children.

Luz works hard to provide for her family. She runs a variety store in the Philippines. She has been in this business for six years and has previously received funds through Kiva. 

Luz requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more items like shampoo, soft-drinks and other groceries.

Luz aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more items like shampoo, soft-drinks and other groceries.

loans.name: Imarika Group

texts.en:
Abdahal is a micro entrepreneur who has been running a café selling juices, water, milk, and food for six years. He is a married man in his late 30s with four children ( two boys and two girls);  three are in school while one is finished with school. He works from 6am to 6pm daily, and is able to earn a good profit each month. 

This will be his fifth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. With the previous loans, all of which have been repaid, he managed to increase missing cafe items like water. With the profit, he covered household expenses and started building a house.  He will use this loan to buy more cafe water to sell.  He dreams one day to be able to buy a big fridge and start selling ice cream. 

He will share this loan with his loan group 'IMARIKA', which totals 14 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more cafe water to sale.

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en:
Jennifer works hard to support her family. She is married and has a sari-sari (general) store business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for five years.

Jennifer requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell in her sari-sari store.

In the future, Jennifer would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items like shampoo, groceries, etc., to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a divorced mother of three of children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses is household consumables. 

For over one year, she has operated a fruits and vegetables stall business, selling at the the market to her town dwellers and local residents. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in fruits. She dreams of establishing  a grocery business in the future. 

With the KES 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of green vegetables, onions, tomatoes, potatoes, mangoes and oranges. She decided to join Yehu because of availability of a variety of loan products.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of green vegetables, onions, tomatoes, potatoes, mangoes and oranges.

loans.name: Marietta

texts.en:
Marietta is a 48-year-old married woman and a mother of five children from Maribojoc, Bohol. 

She is engaged in a food vending business and has been in the business for more than 17 years now. This is the source of her income. 

Marietta is asking for a loan to buy ingredients for food vending like banana, flour, sugar, glutenuous rice, and food wrappers. 

In the future, Marietta hopes to expand her business and make it successful and sustainable.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for food vending like banana, flour, sugar, glutenuous rice, and food wrappers.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a tailoring business in the Philippines. 

Norma successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her tailoring business.

She is borrowing PHP 29,000 through NWTF to purchase an additional sewing machine.

NWTF is re-listing Norma's business profile in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase an additional sewing machine.

loans.name: Raheli

texts.en:
Raheli is a married woman with three children, two of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and household needs. 

For the past six years, she has operated a fruits and vegetables selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors. She cited seasonality in fruits to be her major challenge. Raheli dreams of establishing a greengrocery business in the future. 

With the Kshs 15,000 she wants to purchase a stock of vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes, onions and kale. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes, onions and kale.

loans.name: Laura

texts.en:
Laura is 37 years old. She lives in Batumi district with her husband and two children. 

Laura’s husband is a goldsmith and gets orders to make jewelry. This is the only source of income for the family. It is hardly enough to feed the family. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Laura has requested loans from local financial institutions several times for family business start-ups, but without any success. Her loan requests were rejected all the time because of low income and family’s poor living conditions. 

Laura requested a loan from Credo to start a family business. Laura has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With this credit, Laura will rent a counter and begin a jewelry trade. She plans to purchase different kinds of jewelry and gold products for resale. As her husband is involved in the jewelry business, she hopes that it will be profitable. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to begin a jewelry trading business.

loans.name: Nelcy

texts.en:
Nelcy is married and she works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from rope-making. Nelcy is borrowing PHP 17,000 through NWTF to purchase more stock of groceries to sell.

Nelcy has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF and more recently, through Kiva. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of groceries to sell.

loans.name: Rania

texts.en:
Rania is a 27-year-old married woman, the mother of one child. She has been working as a hair dresser for eight years. She is very talented in her business, and serves her customers in a very special way. Rania's beauty salon is located in a high population area.
She provides special beauty services that she increases and develops in response to different customer needs.

Rania hopes to add a new service that will increase her income and please her customers, so she is applying for a YOUTH loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua to buy a special facial treatment machine. 

Rania hopes to keep on expanding and developing her business to make sure that her family and customers are having their needs met.

loans.use: To buy a special facial treatment machine for her salon business.

loans.name: Maritza

texts.es: Doña Maritza,48  años de edad  habita en la ciudad de Estelí desde hace muchos años ella se dedica a la elaboración de tortillas, tiene 4 años de dedicarse a este negocio, vende a domicilio y también a comiderias que le encargan por cantidad. Con esta actividad ha mantenido a sus dos hijos que ya son mayores de edad. Ella está solicitando el crédito lo utilizará para la compra de maíz leña, cal y un perol más grande  para agilizar su trabajo  sus metas futuras son arreglar el techo de su cocina donde hecha sus tortillas y sus metas próximas son comprar los productos que necesita para hacer sus tortillas hechas a base de maíz. Su mayor anhelo es mejorar la infraestructura de su humilde hogar.
texts.en:
Doña Maritza, 48, lives in the city of Estelí where for many years she has made a living by making tortillas.  She has spent four years in this business, selling door-to-door and also to eateries that order in large quantities.  With this work she has taken care of her two children who are already older.

She is asking for the loan to buy corn, firewood, lime, and a larger saucepan in order to speed up her work.  Her future goal is to repair the roof of her kitchen where she makes the tortillas, and her current goal is to buy products that she needs in order to make her corn tortillas.  Her greatest desire is to improve the structure of her modest home.

loans.use: to buy corn, firewood, and lime.

loans.name: Jai Durga Group

texts.en: Pira, a 48-year-old married woman, lives in Bhawanipatna of Kalahandi District in Odisha, India. The lady sitting in the front with a raised hand is Pira. She lives with her six-member family comprised of her husband; four sons, ages 30, 28, 25 and 20; and one daughter, age 22. She is a very energetic, hardworking and enthusiastic person who always devotes her time to getting her family ahead. Pira herself has been running a general grocery shop for nine years to maintain her family. Initially, she started the business with a low profile selling limited items like potatoes, soap, sugar, tea dust, tobacco, chocolates, etc. Gradually she expanded her business and added extra items regularly. Apart from this, her two sons have two barber shops and the other two sons are working at other barber shops on a daily wage basis. In the year 2010, Pira and three other women of her locality formed a joint liability group named Jai Durga and took out a loan from Mahashakti Foundation for the development of their businesses. This is the second loan for her group. With the first loans, Pira has been able to add some grocery items like dough, oil, spices, etc. Now she is earning 300 Indian rupees daily from her business – which is very scanty to manage her big family. To add some extra income, Pira wants to add soda and cold drink items to her shop. So, with the present loan, she has planned to buy a refrigerator and cold drinks along with other merchandise to increase her sales and income for her overall development. Pira hopes to build a permanent house for her family and get her sons and daughters married off in a respectable manner. The other three members of the group, Sarmistha, Sanju and Haripriya, are running a tailoring center with tent house, a dry food and tiffin hotel, and a welding center respectively.

loans.use: To pay for a refrigerator and cold drinks.

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
This is Francis, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. He is single and lives with his parents. He helps them by working to provide their everyday needs.

Francis operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families eat home-cooked meals only during evenings when all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. This is not only a normal family tradition but a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to spend cooking gas and food for one or two persons when buying cooked rice and viands cost less than raw food. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community.  He earns a minimum of Php 500 in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments, seasonings and frozen food products. He expects a boost in his income as he expands his business.  

Francis dreams that the food stall will continue to grow and expand and hopes that he will have more sources of income. He meets up with his co-fellowship members to share stories of his work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients like rice, pork, chicken, vegetables and other products needed in his business.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is 47 years old and married with 2 children. She works very hard to provide for them. She runs a variety store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more grocery products to sell.

She has been in this business for three years and sells a variety of items such as snack foods, sardines, noodles and other groceries. In the future, Marilou would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more grocery products to sell.

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en: Rosita is a 49-year-old married woman and a mother of three children from Maribojoc, Bohol. She is engaged in a fish vending business. Rosita is asking for a loan to buy more fish to sell. With this, she will be able to sell more fish thus augmenting her sales and income. In the future, Rosita dreams of becoming a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: to buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is 43 years old and married with four children, one of whom is in school. Juliet works very hard to provide for them. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more groceries to sell.

She has been in this business for four years and sells a variety of items such as shampoo, sugar, sardines and other groceries. In the future Juliet would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Blesilda

texts.en:
Blesilda is a capable entrepreneur. She is a family woman and a mother of two children. She tries to provide a good living and upbringing for her family. She helps her husband solve all the family problems, especially in economic matters. 

She has been involved in selling frozen foods and candies for seven years. She makes a good profit from her business. 

Blesilda wants to obtain a loan of PHP 25,000 to purchase more frozen foods such as ham and hotdogs as well as a variety of candies. She hopes that she will receive this loan so that she can improve their living.

loans.use: to purchase more frozen foods such as ham and hotdogs as well as variety of candies.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
This is Amelia. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more products for her variety store and because of that, she was able to generate more income as well. She is in this business for four years now. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday needs.

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her current inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result for better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Amelia dreams that her business will continue to grow. She meets with her co-fellowship* members every week to share stories of her life and business and to draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Dama

texts.en:
Dama is a married woman with two school-going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is household items.

Dama has operated an open air food selling business, selling from home to local residents. She faces a major challenge of seasonality – especially during the rainy season it becomes hard for her to operate her business. Her goal is to establish a restaurant business in the future.

Dama wants to purchase cooking utensils for her business with this 10,000 Kenyan shilling loan. She decided to join Yehu because it supports small businesses.

loans.use: to purchase cooking utensils for her food selling business

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
For her eighth cycle loan, Melanie is requesting a loan of PHP 22,000 to fund her restaurant business.  

The general store business that she previously funded through NWTF and Kiva continues, and provides Melanie and her family with an improvement to their standard of living.

loans.use: to buy additional utensils and ingredients for her restaurant.

loans.name: Oneyda Del Socorro

texts.es:
Oneyda de 37 años de edad, una  humilde señora de oficio comerciante, se dedica al negocio de pulpería. Agradece por la oportunidad brindada de su primer préstamo, ya que ella se siente muy satisfecha  porque  pudo invertir más en su pulpería comprando los productos que aun no tenía en existencias como arroz, azúcar, gaseosa, frijoles, etc. Ella esta solicitando su segundo financiamiento para seguir invirtiendo en lo mismo de compra de granos básicos como arroz, gaseosa, azúcar, aceite, frijoles. Con el propósito de incrementar cada  día mas sus ganancias.
Una de sus metas es poder brindarle un mejor servicio a su clientela y a la misma vez tener una calidad de vida mejor  con su familia.
texts.en:
Oneyda is 37 years old and is a humble businesswoman.  She has a general store and is grateful for the opportunity provided by her first loan and is very satisfied because she was able to invest in her store and buy the products that she didn’t have, such as rice, sugar, soft drinks, beans, etc.  She is asking for a second loan so that she can continue doing the same and buy basic grains such as rice, soft drinks, sugar, cooking oil, and beans.  She wants to increase her earnings.

One of her goals is to be able to provide better service to her customers and at the same time have a better quality of life for her family.

loans.use: to stock her store.

loans.name: Yohana

texts.en:
Yohana has a kiosk where many people come to buy every day. She wants to buy some additional supplies such as biscuits, noodles, sugar, coffee, milk, cooking oil, and a refrigerator to keep the drinks and other things.

A $1,200 loan was offered to Yohana to improve her business. 

She has been doing business activities since 2006. She feels so comfortable to run her business because she can earn money every day.

loans.use: to buy biscuits, noodles, sugar, coffee, milk, cooking oil, and a refrigerator.

loans.name: Kakakuona Group

texts.en:
Method, who is in her late 20s, is married and has a boy who is in school. For a period of five years now, Method has been earning a living by running a shop, selling different food items like rice, maize flour, sugar, salt, etc. She is doing fine in this project. She works from 6:00am to 9:30pm daily and is able to make a fair profit every month. 

This will be her 16th loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to expand her business by purchasing more foods items and by increasing the amount of sugar, rice, etc. With the expansion, she gained more clients. With the profit, she managed to cover household expenses and started building a house for her family. She has paid back all her loans successfully. She will use this loan to restock food items in her shop. She wants to finish building the family's house. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "Kakakuona", which totals 10 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to restock food items in her shop.

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en: Mercelita is a 41-year-old married woman from Ubay, Bohol. She is the mother of a 15-year-old-daughter. She is engaged in farming. She grows rice. She has been growing rice for more than 10 years. She requested a loan of 13,000 PHP to buy trapal (tarp) or laminated sacks used for the rice to dry after it is harvested. Mercelita would like to expand her business to support her child, especially for her education.

loans.use: to buy trapal (tarp) or laminated sacks used  for the rice to dry.

loans.name: October

texts.en:
October, 24 years old, lives with her husband and son in Darkhan, the second largest city of Mongolia. The family resides in their own house, which was repaired last year using her previous loan. 

Her husband has position of teacher at a high school. She has been making Mongolian traditional shoes since 2008 and selling them to vendors at Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Lately, the demand for Mongolian traditional shoes has increased drastically, so she is requesting a loan of 3,500,000 MNT to purchase materials such as leather, textiles and steel for making shoes. With the loan, she can make and sell Mongolian traditional shoes without worrying about inventory shortages. The borrower is a very trustworthy and hardworking woman.

loans.use: to purchase materials used for making Mongolian traditional shoes.

loans.name: Tasianah

texts.en:
Tasianah is a married woman with seven children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past five years, she has operated a firewood selling business, selling from home to her local neighbors. She faces the challenge of the high cost of transportation from rural areas to her place of operation. 

With the loan that she is requesting she wants to purchase bundles of firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood for resale.

loans.name: Mwanapili

texts.en:
Mwanapili is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school while one is still young for school. She owns a house that has neither  electricity or piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For over two years, she has operated an open air food business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Mwanapili dreams of establishing a restaurant business.

With the KES 10,000 loan, she wants to establish a vegetable stall business, and purchase green vegetables, potatoes, tomatoes, and onions for sale. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables, potatoes, tomatoes, and onions to sell.

loans.name: Adrian
